Review: to me, mattei's films feel like remembered dreams about other films. this one is like a giallo/THE DEVILS/THE EXORCIST/CARRIE mash-up. i mean, yeah, it drags a lot and has scenes that are almost completely in the dark, but it also kinda works?

Name: Pink Flamingos
Review: i love that this is so clearly the work of someone obsessed with herschel gordon lewis schlock and the manson family. still hilarious and perfect in how it accomplishes everything it sets out to do.

Name: Blood Feast
Review: it gets slow, even for being under 70 minutes, but it’s still a lot of fun and weird. lauren was expecting the ending to involve everyone at the party eating the prepared body parts, but i don’t think herschel has made anything even close to nihilistic.
Tags: streaming, shudder, the last drive-in, with-lauren

Name: Antropophagus
Review: some effective moments bundled with a lot of looking around a gorgeous greek (?) island ghost town.

Name: The Wicker Man
Review: to be honest, i kinda dig that the cult is actively seeking out sacrifices as opposed to it being a last-ditch effort. and also that they seem to be targeting cops.

Name: The Silence
Review: this is a family that all knows how to use sign language and yet there are so many scenes of them whispering. it’s schlocky and decidedly Not Good, but i had more fun watching this than A QUIET PLACE.

Name: Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse
Review: cried a whole lot more this time. gosh it’s just  perfect.

Name: The Hole in the Ground
Review:
the first half is straight-up chef-kisses mood-building. there’s a sequence where we see a character reacting to something terrifying, for a prolonged period of time, and we never see it. so satisfyingly unsatisfying.

there are a few missteps, storytelling + visually, in the direction of showing/telling too much, but most of the film is spent withholding large bits of information.

Name: Psychos in Love
Review: i was completely charmed by this, but i totally understand why it won’t work for some. it has the spirit of an early 90s film with the aesthetics of straight-to-video 80s horror and john waters. has a for-real great theme song.

Name: But I'm a Cheerleader
Review: it took me 20 years to see this but it honestly wouldn’t have been as important to me if i had seen it earlier. extra half-star for the soundtrack which is just delightful.

Name: They Paid with Bullets: Chicago 1929
Review:
for some reason, it’s strange to see a european take on the american prohibition gangster film. entirely watchable on-the-cheap fare. everything feels kinda off, but not distractingly so. 

features the same stretch of road + painted trees in spain as THE PASSENGER, i think?

Name: Hide and Seek
Review: there are a bunch of solid moments throughout; they’re just whenever robert de niro is off-screen. dakota fanning, however, is fantastic.

Name: Taking Lives
Review: wow, this is rough. it’s somehow an a-list version of a bad csi episode. it wants to be SE7EN for the first hour but with a romance arc. ethan hawke does a weird tom cruise impression all the way through.

Name: Tombs of the Blind Dead
Review: some effective set pieces and a great score. so many shots of the templars riding horses in slow motion and honestly i’m here for it.

Name: Assault in Paradise
Review: wow, oliver reed is bonkers in this. why doesn’t his character have a whole run of films a la DIRTY HARRY?

Name: The Nun
Review: wish we could hear what happened with little stefan who was stricken with blindness.

Name: Heroes for Hire
Review:
it’s kind of a slog to get through — and the three or four double-crosses don’t make it easy to follow — but you’re rewarded with a few great nuggets if you make it through:

- a shoot-out in a pizza hut
- a map to the secret location is tattooed (?) on a girlfriend’s butt
- there’s a great sequence two-thirds in where we’re introduced to the said HEROES FOR HIRE in a series of vignettes of them doing their job
- “cactus”, one of the heroes, is getting a haircut when a robbery breaks out, so he calmly strolls to the bank and shoots the bad guys
- there’s a ninja character
- said ninja character spawns four shadow ninjas (according to the subtitles), kills four bad guys, and then they disappear

Name: Backcountry
Review: the bear attack is legit terrifying but you’re stuck with some awful characters for a while before that.

Name: American Movie
Review: this absolutely needs a special edition with a “where are they now?” feature. like, how are mark’s kids? what’s joanie up to? how’s ken keene?

Name: Chained for Life
Review: an okay drama with a lot of vaudeville segments — which are fun enough to watch. the hilton sisters are charming too.

Name: Funeral Parade of Roses
Review: has the same glee you find in godard’s 60s films and I AM CURIOUS where every splice is unpredictable and exciting. i never imagined wanting to be stoned in a tiny room with a bunch of strangers dancing.

Name: Hollywood Vice Squad
Review: kinda feels like two episodes of a tv show mashed together; i can’t say for certain how the carrie fisher plot wraps up. but it’s fun and goofy and interesting to look at in parts.

Name: The Driller Killer
Review: out-grimes MANIAC with the inclusion of the most unappetizing pizza i’ve ever seen. in reno’s defense, hearing that band practice every night would drive me to killing as well.

Name: Masters of the Universe
Review: a whole lot more enjoyable than i was expecting. loved the costumes & skeletor’s gold outfit.

Name: God Knows Where I Am
Review: lori singer’s performance reading linda’s diaries is worth a watch alone. the story is devestating and, for the most part, the telling of it is solid.

Name: The Sixth Sense
Review: it’s been a minute since i’ve seen this. i definitely didn’t remember the script being as good as it is. though, i’d be interested in seeing this edited to focus less on bruce willis and moreso haley joel osment / toni collette.

Name: Midsommar
Review: this kinda felt like an eli roth script? the crowd i saw it with really got some laughs but was also audibly upset during some sequences. i dug it: there are some legit great moments that happen to some flat characters.

Name: The 400 Blows
Review: antoine’s flannel jacket is ICONIC

Name: Fatal Bond
Review: there’s like three plot lines in this and they’re all just barely tied together. linda blair’s character is incredibly clueless. maybe worth a watch because the way it unfolds is kinda wild.

Name: Thought Crimes
Review: interesting enough, though it definitely looks like a first feature.

Name: I Love You, Now Die: The Commonwealth v. Michelle Carter
Review: imagine being in court and people you thought were your friends are on the stand talking about actively avoiding hanging out with you.

Name: Midsommar
Review: gosh ari aster’s so good at getting eerie images stuck in my head.

Name: Munchausen
Review: bonnie bedelia is so good. bonus points for the goofy posters/labels/book covers (“uncle dad” and “mao way or the high way” stand out).

Name: Secret Obsession
Review: the creepy (?) bearded guy who gets killed is supposed to be a red herring, right? it seems like he just shows up to act suspicious.

Name: A Nightmare on Elm Street
Review:
i’m fascinated by how wes craven’s movies went from raw & gritty to a pretty generic studio look starting with this one. 

also, dude’s name is definitely “dave-rod” right? i’m not mishearing that?

Name: A Nightmare on Elm Street Part 2: Freddy's Revenge
Review: kim meyers’ looks are iconic.

Name: A Nightmare on Elm Street 3: Dream Warriors
Review: so that hospital’s totally closed and nancy and that doctor are totally vilified for having like six deaths happen on their watch, right?

Name: The Immoral Three
Review:
a nudie that’s also some kind of giallo? it’s weird but doris makes it work. i feel like it’s the weakest of the AGENT 73 trilogy simply because it’s missing chesty morgan. but it’s still a wild ride at points. 

the banana blow-job close-up footage overlapped with the man’s face moaning in ecstasy is iconic.

Name: The Invasion
Review:
this could’ve been so much worse? honestly, get rid of most of the cgi and weird editing flourishes and you’ve got a decent little thriller. 

veronica cartwright getting tazed was really sad to watch.

Name: Bob le Flambeur
Review: gosh, this is just a perfect french film-noir. such a wild split between character-piece and heist film.

Name: Major League
Review: this has so many fantastic gags that i’m willing to give a pass on those that didn’t age well (as well as that romantic subplot, though rene russo is great).

Name: Free Radicals: A History of Experimental Film
Review: i need to see more maya deren films

Name: Rats: Night of Terror
Review: so far, my favorite of the mattei/fragasso collaborations. so weird and goofy.

Name: Flowers in the Attic
Review: going in blind’s probably the best way to approach this – i only knew vc andrews from her die-cut book covers. the plot is insane; the actual film is... fine?

Name: Bad Black
Review: pure love of film and uganda. the roadshow version (?) is an avalanche of action scenes and vj emmie narration.

for me, this really worked when folks were talking about the actual edits as well as putting the film in a historical context. otherwise, i was just wondering why they included some of the talking heads who just are there to praise PSYCHO.

Name: Once Upon a Time… in Hollywood
Review: more like chekhov’s flamethrower amirite?

Name: The Great Hack
Review: i can't tell if i'm impressed or baffled by the cambridge analytical gal thinking "sure, i'll be interviewed for this documentary while in a fancy pool in thailand"

Name: Bad Lieutenant
Review:
the scene where keitel's waiting to get drug money and is sitting on the couch with his guy's mom and then he staggers down the stairwell was incredible.

i think i saw the r-rated version: the scene where he pulls over the two girls was abbreviated from what i've read.

Name: Hot Cars
Review: a pretty solid quickie noir that gets elevated by a climactic fight that takes place on an actual roller coaster.

Name: Garry Winogrand: All Things Are Photographable
Review: i wish i could remember it to quote it here, but the excerpt from his guggenheim (?) grant application where he talks about the worries and anxieties and apocalyptic feels of the early 60s -- and his desire to dig deeper because he couldn't accept the conclusion that everything is fucked -- really hit me hard.

Name: Detour
Review: my platonic ideal of a noir film

Name: Dial M for Murder
Review: it kinda stalled for me in the back third, but the first hour is so good.

Name: Luz
Review: enigmatic and hypnotic. some details left me confused but like not in an unsatisfied way. so glad this lived up to the hype of the trailer.

Name: The Watcher
Review: it’s all fun and games until the big twist in the last ten minutes. the “raven” costume is effective but gosh those creepy notes are not.

Name: Freddy's Dead: The Final Nightmare
Review: not as bad as i remembered it but definitely not very good. yaphet kotto is great but underused. wild that there are _two_ goo goo dolls song + a main theme by iggy pop in this.

Name: The Bye Bye Man
Review: the bye-bye man needs to pick one or two character traits/accessories and stick with them. one of: creepy skin, large robe, dog sidekick, gold coins, random train passing nearby.

Name: The Autopsy of Jane Doe
Review: starts off with some solidly spooky atmosphere and a great brian cox role (bummer he’s stuck alongside shitty emile hirsch) but completely falls apart in the last half hour.

Name: The Conversation
Review: BLOW-UP for post-watergate america

Name: Chained Girls
Review: trashy and campy at spots. the apartment wedding with four guests and a gay man officiating is my dream.

Name: A Nightmare on Elm Street: The Dream Child
Review: ends with a diss-track — apparently directed at ll cool j — for some reason. legit surprised that FREDDY'S DEAD got green-lit after this.

Name: Girl Gang
Review: cheapo jd film that’s more about teens smoking “weeds” and shooting heroin (i think they refer it as “joy pops”?) than “girl gang” activity. some strange editing decisions abound and a great harp flourish whenever the kids get high.

Name: Meshes of the Afternoon
Review: really makes me feel silly for being like “i don’t wanna leave my apartment but there’s nothing to do” all the time

Name: Eaux d'artifice
Review: feels like we’re peeking in on someone running around a park in the moonlight. the editing in this is great; as is the effect of the lady disappearing into the water.

Name: Sun Don't Shine
Review: a mumblecore BADLANDS and i’m absolutely here for it.

Name: Hard Ticket to Hawaii
Review: this is so much fun. feels like a late-night showtime riff on MIAMI VICE or THE A-TEAM. the last thirty minutes are fantastic: it’s like watching the script realize that it keeps forgetting about characters or plot points to wrap up.

Name: Red Roses of Passion
Review: there are maybe a dozen camera setups throughout but they’re all kind of beautiful – the shot of carla spiking her aunt’s tea is particularly memorable. hypnotic and strange and never boring.

Name: Olivia
Review: shockingly gay for 1951. like, there is zero subtext whatsoever. and that was fantastic. i spent maybe the first 40 minutes trying to figure out who was an adult and who was a student and how old everyone was.

Name: Scorpio Rising
Review: a horned-up love poem daydream about bad boys

Name: Moonstruck
Review: i would watch a MR HULOT-esque feature of cher’s grandfather and his five dogs and their wacky misadventures.

Name: The Life and Death of 9413, a Hollywood Extra
Review: the german-expressionistic title card cutouts are so neat and great to look at

Name: Fitzcarraldo
Review: werner herzog’s APOCALYPSE NOW

Name: Burden of Dreams
Review:
les blank’s HEARTS OF DARKNESS: A FILMMAKER’S APOCALYPSE. 

from everything i’ve heard about how erratic klaus kinski was throughout the making of FITZCARRALDO, he seems okay in this footage. 

also, the footage of jason robards and mick jagger was rough and i can’t imagine how drab the film would’ve turned out had they been in the final product.

Name: High School Hellcats
Review: pretty decent teenage girl-gang entry that starts strong and fizzles out about halfway in. i tend to dig this genre more when the bad girls are the focus (a la THE VIOLENT YEARS); this gang seems more like a bunch of goodies that are afraid of the ringleaders. bonus points for the cool abandoned movie theater location.

Name: Deadly Switch
Review: wild that netflix is getting all the sub-lifetime movies

Name: Blood and Black Lace
Review: cool, swanky, fun, and cruel. the trumpet theme sums up the vibe more than i think i ever could.

Name: Prince of Darkness
Review: so i’ve learned this is not one you’ll be able to follow if you’re drifting in and out of sleep. i’ve completely flipped on it. i loved it. i loved the images. i loved how unabashedly convoluted the details are. i’m shocked that i thought the end of the world would be clear and understandable.  it’s an apocalyptic demonic possession movie that’s also a zombie movie?

Name: The Great Silence
Review: beautiful and bleak. love a reserved kinski.

Name: Moonlighting Wives
Review: come for the catchy theme song, stay for the great sarno setups. he also edits this movie in a winking way that i was totally charmed by.

Name: Cannibal Holocaust
Review: i forgot how much time is spent just getting to the discovery of the footage. also forgot how well-done jack’s disembowling is.

Name: Night Moves
Review: the tension it creates by showing the minutia of the preparations is fantastic. looking at jesse eisenberg be tense for almost two hours put a kink in my neck.

Name: Strangers on a Train
Review: sure, robert walker’s great, but how about pat hitchcock? i just want to watch her the whole time, what with farley granger and ruth roman just being so bland.

Name: The Decline of Western Civilization
Review: a great document of a scene i know next to nothing about. stoked to learn that i never need to listen to fear again.

Name: Psycho Stripper
Review: it has a few opportunities to go off the rails but doesn’t really do anything?

Name: Big Trouble in Little China
Review: wasn’t expecting to be as charmed by this as i was. kate burton looked so familiar but i don’t think i’ve seen anything else she’s been in.

Name: Hunt to Kill
Review:
honestly, this could’ve been so much worse. i would’ve loved to have seen eric roberts in more of this, but there isn’t really anything for him to do. steve austin is perfectly fine. i guess everyone is perfectly fine. 

points for a SCARFACE quote (“shoot this piece of shit”) and a wild kinda-death-by-atv.

Name: Mystery of the Seeing Hand and Golden Sphere
Review: the animation of the egg cracking got me wondering what lynch is like when editing something. like, how open is he to playing around? or is he like "nope, this is how i'm seeing it"?

Name: All the Colors of the Dark
Review: imagine moving to a new city, you’re having crazy nightmares, someone’s stalking you, and your new friend is like “hey, i think my friends and i can help” and then she takes you inside a kenneth anger movie.

Name: Midsommar
Review:
wasn’t expecting the director’s cut additions to be as helpful as they are? they fleshed things out for the most part. really in love with the ending at this point. 

shout out to the group of 8 kids who snuck in right before the elders jump off the cliff and left right after the scene ended. stoked to see that live on.

Name: The Third Eye
Review: some grim vibes all over this gothic giallo. the set-pieces built for suspense (like the gas station one) are super effective, but patches throughout are kind of dull and murky.

Name: Revenge
Review: the tension building is *chef’s kisses*. it gets weirder (and gorier) than i was expecting which was a welcome surprise.

Name: The Texas Chainsaw Massacre 2
Review:
the movie rob zombie’s been trying to make for a large part of his career. the humor worked for me, and the wackiness helps distract from the sloppiness (there’s a scene under a table where a loud fight is ensuing and none of that fight is audible during the monologue).


forgot just how little dennis hopper is in this. bummer.

Name: The Vanishing
Review: edge of my seat even though i remembered the plot beats. absolutely recommend watching it again with someone who hasn’t seen it before

Name: Lake Mungo
Review: who killed alice palmer?

Name: It Chapter Two
Review: bummer that the scariest part of this was the teaser trailer w/ jessica chastain. might be more of a mess than the first one but now with thirty more minutes of cgi ghoulies.

Name: The Killing
Review: absolutely solid noir picture. sterling hayden is still the hottest dude in this era. always love to watch elisha cook be elisha cook. ALSO i don’t know if the guy who plays nikki can’t open his mouth when he talks or if it was a character choice but it made the character so intimidating.

Name: Kate Plays Christine
Review: this is such an interesting/fun/weird essay film. occasionally excessive but kinda enthralling as it goes on. it’s fascinating to watch kate lyn sheil gradually turn into what she thinks is christine chubbuck (whom she can’t find footage of).

Name: Meek's Cutoff
Review: beautiful and sparse. so much of this is spent teetering the edge between relief and dread.

Name: Chopping Mall
Review: TERMINATOR in the style of a teen slasher.

Name: A Vigilante
Review: this starts out really promising and i was kinda hoping we wouldn’t learn any details about sadie’s past. still, though, olivia wilde is great, and the direction is promising.

Name: Silver Bullets
Review: kept me interested in seeing where it was going, for the most part. there’s a neat twist about two-thirds in, but the novelty of it is kinda squashed with an epilogue.

Name: Halloween
Review: (sub)urban legend

Name: One Cut of the Dead
Review: the second half of this is so incredibly fun and charming. fantastic execution of a clever idea. loved it.

Name: My Body Hungers
Review: “melodramatic sexploitation murder mystery” is a genre i would love to see more of. the shots aren’t as interesting as RED ROSES OF PASSION and the entire climax is shot in day-for-night. but the sarno melodrama makes it enjoyable.

Name: The Sacrament
Review:
gene jones’ performance during the first interview. good night.


like most found footage movies, this probably didn’t need to be a found footage movie.


also, kate lyn sheil went and learned a pretty solid australian accent and they have the audacity to use her for one scene.

Name: October Sky
Review: dramatic comfort food that’s surprisingly anti-union. jake gyllenhaal, chris cooper, and natalie canerday all give performances that i find unforgettable. love to throw this on every few years and get a few good tears out.

Name: I Don't Want to Be Born
Review: all of the baby attacks are done via editing between a baby being cute and someone recoiling with blood on their face (“he scratched me!”). it’s great.

Name: Event Horizon
Review: the music over the titles is a prodigy song called “the funky shit” in case you weren’t aware this was made in 1997. always love starting this, always let down by the back-half. also, what’s up with them treating the young buck like a ten year old child?

Name: The New York Ripper
Review: “in this country, if you’re not good at something, at anything, if you’re not the best, the smartest, or the toughest, that’s it. you’re screwed! you won’t get anywhere.” strange to see 70s new york grime through and italian lens. maybe it’s the (what seems like) italian sets that don’t exactly jive with the shots outdoors. the shots of 42nd street have me wishing i could go back in time. it’s not exactly a huge twist who the killer is, but the motivation – revealed with about 15 minutes left in the movie – is certainly something unique. count me as a fan of the donald duck voice, for sure.

Name: Don't Go in the House
Review: a proto-MANIAC (by months, i think?) set outside the city. kinda long-winded in spots but also contains some great late-70s small-town scenery (the bar where donny picks up the two girls is something i’ve seen all my life but rarely/never in a movie). the character bobby is so sweet throughout, even when he’s cheating on his wife.

Name: The Taking of Deborah Logan
Review: jill larson and anne ramsay give fantastic performances but it’s ultimately just another found-footage movie with all of its trappings. i was hoping there would be more ambiguity about whether deborah’s acting strange because of her alzheimer’s or being possessed, but once you see someone jump cut from standing on the floor to standing on a stove in what’s supposed to be real-time that just goes out the window.

Name: A Bucket of Blood
Review: schlocky perfection that’s also really funny.  wasn’t expecting it to nail both fronts but it really does. my kingdom for a catalog of walter’s works with words by maxwell brock.

Name: The Fourth Kind
Review: i love this because it really swings for the fences, even if it doesn’t totally succeed. i still find it fascinating just as a filmic concept.

Name: Color Me Blood Red
Review:
lewis/friedman give their spin on the corman concept (i guess? apparently murderous artists is a common theme?) with diminishing results. it’s not as fun as the others in the blood trilogy. 

i wanna know so much more about the couple that are friends with the main teen gal. they’re kooky and goofy and so much more interesting than the other squaresville pair.

Name: A Hot Night at the Go-Go Lounge!
Review: cute go-go dancing curio featuring maybe the ugliest khaki pants you could put in a nudie short and an instrumental version of la bamba.

Name: Goth
Review: TRAINING DAY for high school outcasts as crissy and her wiener boyfriend are taken around town by a girl named “goth” in the back of a van (whose driver we never see) and put through a series of initiations. cheap SOV movie that’s kinda silly but at least it’s not a slog to get through.

Name: The Ritual
Review: y’all can miss me with that hiking for days in a foreign country garbage. some solid mood-building and shockingly not-awful creature design (it helps when the movie doesn’t show too much).

Name: Slugs
Review: if PIECES is juan piquet simón’s take on slasher movies, this is his 1950s monster movie. just as batshit and slightly more straightforward.

Name: The Psychic
Review: absolutely solid supernatural murder-mystery from fulci. a lot of fun to piece together and even if you’re slow to put together the clues of how this ends, you’ll probably still figure it out before the movie reveals it (eg. the same revelatory flashback dialogue is repeated two or three times in the last half).

Name: Threads
Review: the sense of dread in the first half is so thick and then things just get worse. i didn’t realize that i’ve never seen the cold war from outside of an american perspective and that made the feeling of helplessness worse. also made me realize how ill-prepared for something like a nuclear attack everyone i know is.

Name: A Nightmare on Elm Street
Review: nancy’s mom drinking secret-closet-vodka is my forever mood.

Name: A Nightmare on Elm Street Part 2: Freddy's Revenge
Review: we’re really not gonna address ron being grounded for throwing his grandmother down a flight of stairs?

Name: Joker
Review: “KILL THE RICH: A NEW MOVEMENT?”

Name: The Blob
Review: i kinda feel like this and TWIN PEAKS exist in the same universe.

Name: Final Curtain
Review: this feels like ed wood filmed a bunch of footage and then improvised a monologue for it. think a boring TWILIGHT ZONE episode written by someone getting paid by the word.

Name: Torso
Review: solid giallo that’s both a campus whodunnit and home invasion. i personally dug the latter half more if only because it’s not completely filled with gross dudes leering.

Name: Rabid
Review: a lot of the infected-attacking sequences sound absurd (like: “santa clays gets shot with a machine gun) but the script manages to get there in a logical way. my cronenberg exposure is limited but this was a lot more fun than i expected. but also believably bleak.

Name: Lyle
Review: i really dug this, warts and all. sign me up for queer mumblecore genre exercises. even while it follows the ROSEMARY’S BABY bulletpoints it still managed to make some interesting divergences. the cast is good, but gaby hoffman stands out as exceptional.

Name: Grotesque
Review:
it’s wild that there was a point in time where special effects artists were so notable that several movies could include them as protagonists. 

y’all this changes genres/tones like four times and has maybe the oddest final fifteen minutes i can recall. i would’ve sworn this had been restored by the boutique obscure horror video houses but i guess it hasn’t?

not sure if this would be all that great on repeat viewings, but a blind first watch was great.

Name: El Camino: A Breaking Bad Movie
Review: there are a lot of good moments throughout this, which is essentially a curtain call – it fills out the broad strokes of jesse’s fate that i figured were implied at the series’ end. that said, it’s really nice to see most of the gang back. skinny pete and badger were always my favorite side characters on the show and i’m so glad they get a really lovely send-off.

Name: New Year's Evil
Review: wow, guess i’m just not a new wave punk fan? this is alright. points for use of a bag of weed as a weapon.

Name: The Lighthouse
Review: hypnotic and tense and incredibly weird. it’s also funny? the script is chock full of meaty monologues and rants and curses and both dafoe and patterson nail them. i hope the seagull actors got a whole lot of fish for their work.

Name: Uninvited
Review: can’t decide what i loved more: the cat puppet(s) or characters cowering in fear at a confused cat. or clu gallagher drunkenly yelling at a cat to get away from his wine.

Name: Ghosthouse
Review: like the movie you’d see in the background of another movie. come for the completely unspooky ghost girl, stay for the guy falling through the floor into molten cum.

Name: Witchery
Review: SUNSET BOULEVARD gets name-dropped early on but this really is kind of a haunted house sequel.

Name: Racket Girls
Review: would happily trade the cheap gangster plot for more women’s wrestling clips, despite how vanilla they are. only timothy farrell went on to do other movies, which is a bummer: i would love to see another peaches page feature.

Name: Psychomania
Review: i kinda love the simplicity of this universe’s formula for immortality (simply want to die when killing yourself and maybe have a frog medallion near by). but it’s always the assholes that want to live forever.  also, the gang’s helmets are so cool.

Name: The Exorcist III
Review: a little uneven (the ending is a studio idea and it kinda shows) but this is so much better than an “exorcist part three” would lead you to believe. how about that long take at the hospital at night? or that george c. scott monologue about the carp in his bathtub?

Name: The Amityville Horror
Review:
james brolin and margot kidder unraveling are just wonderful. his hair throughout is a vision. 

you can see echoes of this in some of the 2010s horror which is wild. like pacing and editing choices (it really nails the dead silences punctured by a loud noise thing). 

would love to see this in a theater.

Name: Stranger in Our House
Review: wish this had a lot more of lee purcell in evil witch mode, to be honest.

Name: The Little Shop of Horrors
Review:
i’m surprised this wasn’t a stage play first because the script absolutely feels like one. maybe the similarities between a dirt-cheap movie and play are many. 

this and BUCKET OF BLOOD are like two variations on a theme and both are perfect. legitimately surprised at how hilarious this is.

Name: Saw
Review: respect for this as a fresh-out-of-film-school thing, but it’s painfully of its time. 18-year-old me lost their shit at the reveal, 33-year-old me still thinks it’s clever.

Name: Scanners
Review: i don’t think i could give examples, but it gets a little slow and dry throughout for me. still though, what a weird trip.

Name: Macabre
Review: goes on for a lot longer than it needs to – i think we get the reveal of what’s in the freezer with about a half-hour left. in true italian horror style it starts and ends strongly, and the dubbing actors’ accents (when they remember they’re playing new orleans residents) are something else.

Name: Tales from the Darkside: The Movie
Review: there was like a year or two of my childhood where this was always on tv; the first story in particular i must’ve seen a dozen times. good enough to stack next to CREEPSHOW (and way better than its sequel). also: the assassin dude in the cat story is buster “hot hot hot” poindexter. thought he looked familiar.

Name: Don't Hang Up
Review: beautiful midwestern giallo that gets surprisingly mean and icky as it goes on. kinda gripping even when the suspense of “who is the creepy caller??” is squashed pretty early on.

Name: Bride of the Monster
Review: “he tampered in god’s domain” i’m a sucker for ed wood’s blend of science-fiction and the supernatural. bela’s monologue to his old countryman is great; ed really knew how to write for him.
Tags: streaming, amazon prime, ends with nuclear explosion

Name: Bloody Moon
Review: landed more on the “mess” side of the messy-fun spectrum for me.

Name: The Rage: Carrie 2
Review:
SHE’S ALL THAT, but make it spooky. this is the kind of bonkers late-90s horror schlock that i eat up with a spoon (see also BOOK OF SHADOWS: BLAIR WITCH 2). the different film stocks/video format switching seems like it should mean something but gets pretty inconsistent.

whatever. it’s a lot of fun and ends up surprisingly bloody. it successfully portrays high school as terrifying. it also has a soundtrack that contains nu metal and the 90s swing fad that was around for like five weeks.

Name: Boogeymen: The Killer Compilation
Review: fulfills the same need that’s now done by a hundred youtube accounts pitching the “ten creepiest slashers”. thankfully, there aren’t any voiceovers (to me, always the cringiest part) and instead we get little fact sheets written in a very late-90s blair witch-y font.

Name: Halloween 4: The Return of Michael Myers
Review: solid entry in the franchise. danielle harris plays scared really effectively and i kinda dig loomis in vengeance mode. love the ending.

Name: Hands of Steel
Review: TERMINATOR meets OVER THE TOP (kinda) in the desert after climate change turns the country into a wasteland. it’s never dull and actually a lot of fun. the main theme is also legitimately great and i wish it was used more.

Name: Glen or Glenda
Review: “only the infinity of the depths of a man’s mind can really tell the full story” nothing makes my heart sing quite like ed wood in a blonde wig and angora sweater. i wasn’t prepared for how passionate and vulnerable this is — the dream sequence is a masterpiece (even with the unrelated s&m bits). the bela framing device totally works for me as a kind of taunting universe/greek chorus.

Name: Halloween 5: The Revenge of Michael Myers
Review: still watchable even as the worst of the first five HALLOWEEN sequels. it feels like a rejected FRIDAY THE 13TH script, but also has some great performances from donald pleasance and danielle harris. she’s unreal.

Name: Skinner
Review:
if not for the extended blackface bit, this would be an easy recommendation for a stylish and weird 90s horror movie. kind of like THE POSTMAN ALWAYS RINGS TWICE in the TWIN PEAKS universe with traci lords playing a morphine-addicted van helsing. there’s some really interesting stuff here. 

but jeez those fifteen or so minutes of ted raimi doing blackface are such a let-down.

Name: River of Grass
Review: i guess kelly reichardt has just always been That Good. a mid-90s riff on BADLANDS but scorched in floridian heat. always feels fresh and poetic and exciting even when its subjects are none of the above.

Name: Don't Look in the Basement
Review: it’s fine, if a little forgettable. except for maybe the last like four minutes which i bet were used in the trailer.

Name: Stanley
Review: compelling enough to keep your attention through its slightly bloated runtime and your patience is rewarded with a wild series of deaths and a bizarre kidnapping twist.
Tags: dvd, mill creek, outboard motor as weapon

Name: 9 Deaths of the Ninja
Review: campy action fun featuring a new-wave dr. strangelove character protected by a lesbian-led militia. the smoke-filled martial-arts-with-dancers title sequence really gets things off on the right foot.

Name: Dance Hall Racket
Review: not as bad as some of the schlock george weiss was producing at this time; the lenny bruce script has a kind of slice-of-life feel. still, it’s pretty rough. there’s an undercover plot that doesn’t really go anywhere and a character makes so much of a deal about going straight that you’d swear he was about to get knocked off.

Name: All She Wants for Christmas
Review: okay, a second viewing really sold me on this one. it’s absolutely cornball but really got the hook on me.

Name: The Changeling
Review:
i would watch whole movies that expand on each of the plot points within this. like the idea of a house being built over a well where a body was hidden.

there’s a whole lot going on here and if it has any faults it’s over-ambition. but it also has george c. scott calling a child's ghost a “goddamn son of a bitch” and maybe my favorite psychic medium (seriously, the automatic writing sequence is so good).

Name: Stray Cat Rock: Delinquent Girl Boss
Review: oh wow, this is just a whole lot of fun. i’m a sucker for mid-20th century kitchen-sink movies and this certainly checks that box: a mob/boxer story injected with girl gangs and starring a iconic queer biker chick character. it goes on a little long, sure, but when it’s doing its thing it really sings.

Name: Terminator: Dark Fate
Review: this was so unexpectedly fun and exciting and... gay? even when it gets into fast-and-furious set-pieces and false endings it still worked for me. that first half, though. good gravy. and the border detention center sequence was just so cathartic to watch.

Name: Martial Law
Review:
fun straight-to-video martial-arts schlock from the 90s. includes several deadly punches, a comically british henchman, and a pretty great opening scene sponsored by dominos.


look for a “GG ALLEN” graffiti tag in the alley fight scene.

Name: Martial Law II: Undercover
Review:
not as enjoyable as the first, if only because the actor playing steve this time around isn’t super charismatic. like the first, i wish cynthia rothrock had more to do, or at least more fight scenes. 

love that both of these have the big bad wager his henchman in a fight to the death with another bad guy’s henchmen.

Name: Lena's Holiday
Review: being in a foreign country with someone else’s bags and without your reservations and you can’t remember the hotel name is maybe the most stressful thing i can imagine. so many people try to or manage to take advantage of lena throughout the whole movie and yet she goes along because she longs to be in america. the whole thing is tonally a mess: switching between a diamond smuggling plot and a quirky early-90s romcom at a dizzying pace.

Name: Las Vegas Lady
Review: cheap vegas heist movie that acts as a good time capsule of the 70s.

Name: Robowar
Review: another fever dream of a blockbuster from mattei/fragasso/drudi. you know that scene in PREDATOR where the main cast all fire their guns into the forest for an extended period of time? that’s repeated here at least four times.

Name: Vigilante
Review:
it’s a shame there wasn’t a seminal powerviolence band named after robert forster. 


a lot of the first half uses wide lenses in an almost john carpenter way that builds some a-plus tension.

Name: Eye for an Eye
Review: solid 90s entry in the assault revenge genre. the cast is fantastic and they really elevate what’s essentially a prestige lifetime movie. i want a mini-series featuring keith david and philip baker hall’s characters.

Name: Woodshock
Review: there are some moments of pure/haunting beauty during the hallucination sequences that when it comes down to earth it can get a little sloggish. really, whenever we’re watching any character that’s not theresa. as in MELANCHOLIA, kirsten dunst is so good as a bottomed-our depressive.

Name: Dolemite Is My Name
Review:
has the same joy and it-takes-a-village spirit of ED WOOD (with which this shares writers). a whole lot of fun and enough to whet my appetite for rudy ray moore’s movies. 

shout-out to the IMMORAL THREE poster in the dimension pictures meeting room.

Name: Parasite
Review: unexpectedly funny and really tense? the script is insanely good.

Name: A Taste of Flesh
Review: i love the simplicity of the plot, necessary for keeping the locations down to just doris’ apartment. never boring, and there’s a great lesbian dream sequence featuring layla peters in an iconic shirt/tie/blazer/no-pants look.

Name: Brain of Blood
Review: weird/cornball monster schlock from the philippines that’s maybe 15 years too late? except maybe for a prolonged outdoors chase sequence in the final act, this is a whole lot of fun. gor’s facial make-up certainly looks influenced by THE BRAIN THAT WOULDN’T DIE’s final monster, if not the same piece. actually, the two would probably make a good double feature.

Name: The Nightingale
Review: absolutely brutal and devastating for like the entirety of its 2 1/4 hr runtime.

Name: Snowpiercer
Review: this was kind of a tonal mess, with everyone being moody and dour except for tilda swinton and ed harris who are doing a kind of HUNGER GAMES dystopia schtick (and were my favorite parts). also, why doesn’t chris evans look as dirty/disheveled as everyone else in the tail section?: his hair looks fresh and his hat’s right off the mannequin; once in a while he’s got some dirt on his face; his sweater’s got a hole in the shoulder.

Name: The Lighthouse
Review: just the horniest/funniest/weirdest thing and i’m here for it.

Name: Christine
Review: rebecca hall is so good in this that i’m willing to cut the script some slack. like, the puppet show scenes are really on the nose, yet here i am getting a little watery-eyed.

Name: Mondo Cane
Review: woof

Name: The Ice House
Review:
which is worse for a long chase scene: day for night or actually shot at night but using only natural lighting? 

weird scuzz noir that has a regional feel even though imdb says this was filled in los angeles (and also was supposed to star jayne mansfield until she died?). threatens to get dark but never does; but like, in a good way.

Name: All About Christmas Eve
Review: wow, the production is maybe the cheapest i’ve seen in a lifetime movie? the whole thing is pretty rough; it’s trying to do an alternate timeline thing but doesn’t really explain what’s going on.
Tags: streaming, lifetime movie club, with-lauren, xmas

Name: Dolemite
Review: all killer and no filler. i ended up watching this like four times over the past week — i'd run out of time about an hour in for some reason or another — and it never got old. it's sloppy and silly but never feels like it was intended as anything other than a fun ride.

Name: The Sex Perils of Paulette
Review:
has the same hopelessness as BAD GIRLS GO TO HELL and ANOTHER DAY, ANOTHER MAN, but a lot tamer. it’s also entirely narrated (save for a brief bookend) and kind of drags at parts. 

i wonder if susan from the first party had been in anything else. she has a cool look.

Name: Home Alone
Review: everyone is great in this but john candy really had to go and show them up in just like 5 minutes of screen time.

Name: Curse of the Vampires
Review: weird gothic vampire schlock with some beautiful (bava-esque?) lighting. i’m not crazy about old castle talkers, but this has the charm to make it enjoyable.

Name: Stripped to Kill
Review: kinda plays out like a nudie cutie in that the plot is paper-thin and the runtime is split with stripping sequences. the gaze is totally different, though, and focuses on the dancing using wider shots and limited cuts. interesting but a little long in the tooth.

Name: The Queen
Review: ugh i loved every second of this. my kingdom for more time spent with miss crystal throughout.

Name: Dial Code Santa Claus
Review: HOME ALONE for kids who grew up watching 80s action cheese. it doesn’t go as far as it threatens to which is for the best. i can’t think of anything more holly-jolly than an action movie final battle prep montage set to a bonnie tyler song called “happy birthday christmas.”

Name: The Irishman
Review:
- the digital de-aging isn’t super distracting. to be honest, there were more green screens and digital bullet-holes that felt sloppier. 

- i don’t have a wide range of scorsese experience, but this is definitely the most reserved movie of his that i can recall. 

- the whole cast is great (esp. pesci); of the supporting cast though, welker white was maybe my favorite. only knowing her as the babysitter in GOODFELLAS, i thought she really held her own. 

- the first half is essentially scorsese’s JFK, which i was kinda hoping it would turn into.

Name: Gremlins
Review: i was worried this was one of those “you had to have seen it as a kid” cases and then the mogwai eat after midnight and all hell breaks loose. it’s kind of meaner than i was expecting but they also yeet the town scrooge out a window so it’s not all bad.

Name: The Hookers
Review:
trashy exposé drama about why three women (individually) got into sex work. the first story has an interesting racial dynamic – a black woman starts doing it as a way to take money from white men as payback for her being raped by two hicks as a child; the flashback of which is legitimately terrifying. the other segments are fine – the third had a twist in that it’s the narrator’s story. 

there’s a swanky music cue that i know i’ve heard somewhere  maybe another one of these movies.

Name: Booksmart
Review: wow, they really just went and made the perfect graduating-high-school-comedy in 2019.

Name: High Life
Review: beautiful and meditative and drenched in fluids. like a hornier SOLARIS that’s also about a guy and his daughter flying towards oblivion? i could’ve sat through another hour of this.

Name: The Wind
Review:
there’s some really solid atmosphere here, good performances too, but it occasionally resorts to of-its-era “spooky imagery” for pay-offs that aren’t necessary.

really got me wondering if i could have lived alone on the prairie? maybe? though, not if i thought i heard knocking in the middle of the night.

Name: The Human Tornado
Review:
i mean, it’s got an instant replay (“so y’all don’t believe i jumped, huh?”) and dolemite hypnotizes the mob boss’s wife with a sexy painting and then has sex with her until the literal roof caves in and she gives up the secret location. 

it’s fantastic.

Name: A Girl Walks Home Alone at Night
Review: hypnotic and beautiful; at times i kinda get a “bela tarr’s SIN CITY” vibe (though that might have to do with the long shots at night in a desolate area). are there a lot of The Girl cosplayers? there should be, she’s iconic.

Name: Mary Jane's Not a Virgin Anymore
Review: the riot-grrl counterpoint to CLERKS (and SLACKER by proxy) that’s full of charm, great outfits, indistinguishable boys, and drinking. a classic.

Name: Orgy of the Dead
Review: criswell and a fake elvira host a topless dance party in a cemetery with a captive white-bread couple as guests of honor. there’s also a wisecracking mummy/wolfman duo and beefcake guards. a whole lot of silly/campy fun with that good-good ed wood dialogue. this needs to be a halloween tradition.

Name: Fanny & Alexander
Review: completely forgot about the scene where emelie mourns by pacing back and forth and screaming. wept immediately.

Name: Fleshpot on 42nd Street
Review: what i would give for a cherry lane/simmons sisters/billy feature. this feels like the result of a bunch of close friends who are super comfortable with each other making a movie over a weekend. like early john waters if he grew up in new york and wasn’t trying to scare the straights.

Name: Zombie 3
Review: this should been so much more of a mess, given it’s production history. it plays as a collection of zombie attack sequences without a lot of connective tissue. but it never really grinds to a halt in the last half the way some fragasso/mattei collaborations do. i mean, it’s still a mess, but it’s totally watchable.

Name: Uncut Gems
Review:
the “this is how i win” speech is just so good. and kinda gut-wrenching. 

i read an interview with the safdies talk about someone saying the last 15 minutes are incredibly tense and they point out it’s really the last 45 minutes and it really is just like that.

Name: Humanoids from the Deep
Review: environmental creature feature that moves at a pretty decent clip. i’m super curious to know how this plays as originally intended – w/o the inserted nudity – though i did like the stinger ending.

Name: Ecco
Review: pretty scattershot but also not nearly as cringe-y as i was expecting (well, until the last 20 minutes which include a woman castrating a reindeer with her teeth). some of these segments i would want watch to watch again.

Name: The Forbidden
Review: i can’t really tell what was shot for this and what was taken from somewhere else; it’s like a weird collage of stripping, short film “re-enactments”, and sleeze.

Name: The Notorious Bettie Page
Review:
a solid biopic with a good cast. there’s an interesting use of stock-footage as establishing shots during the black and white scenes that seemed like a novel approach.

how terrifying is that scene early on where she gets asked on a date and ends up surrounded by strange men? scariest thing i’ve seen in a while.

Name: The Hitch-Hiker
Review: so much of the atmosphere is built up with a long march towards doom. beautiful contrasty photography. best supporting actor nominee for william talman’s right eye.

Name: Rage to Kill
Review:
- our main dude is a french-accented rocket-car-racing (ex?-)-marine named BLAINE STRIKER
- cameron mitchell is undercover as a russian-accented henchman before he’s revealed to be undercover cia and then he has a few rah-rah speeches
- oliver reed is drunk through most of his scenes. 
- the first half hour feels like a whole movie, so the rest kinda drags. but jeez is there a lot of gold sprinkled throughout. would love to watch this with a crowd.

Name: Green
Review: builds a weird sexually-tense atmosphere with beautiful outdoors shots and great performances (though sophia takal’s southern drawl is pretty rough).

Name: Always Shine
Review: starts out as a great character piece and then the moon blinks out and things get really weird. i loved this.
